Dominique Venner (1935â€“2013) was a French historian, essayist, and political activist that was born the son of a member of the fascist Parti populaire franÃ§ais ("French Popular Party"). Venner reported for duty at the outset of the Algerian War in 1954 and fought the Algerian National Liberation Front for two years. Back in France, he joined the national-revolutionary and anticommunist movement Jeune Nation ("Young Nation"), trying to instrumentalize the political tensions caused by the decolonization wars to topple the Fourth Republic. In 1961, he was sentenced to 18 months in jail for his involvement in the right wing Organisation de lâ€™armÃ©e secrÃ¨te ("Organization of the Secret Army"), publishing his activist manifesto "For a Positive Critique" after his release.Executing the steps towards the creation of a national-revolutionary cadre group posited in that book, Venner founded Europe-Action and the eponymous journal in 1963. He also founded various other organizations in subsequent years, including the Groupement de recherche et dâ€™Ã©tudes pour la civilisation europÃ©enne (GRECE; "Research and Study Group for European Civilization") in 1968 which remains essential to this day. Besides his political activities, Venner wrote numerous nonfiction books about weaponry, hunting, politics, and especially contemporary history, many of which won awards. He also edited several political magazines.By late afternoon of May 21, 2013, Dominique Venner took his own life in front of the altar of Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris. As stated in his farewell notes, he hoped to startle the French and all Europeans out of their deadly sleep by this means.
